Dialog.Content: But wrath is like a blade with the sharpest edge. If you aren’t careful with wielding it, you might end up cutting yourself before you even realize it.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: So it’s important to hold that blade correctly.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: And the next step would be deciding where to point your sharp blade.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You’re right, I gotta be careful not to cut myself with it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Although… I already knew where to point my blade from the start.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That’s that, and this is this.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: …Want a cig?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Fine. Just for today.

Group.GroupName: Chesed – Social Sciences / Those who are Faithful and Trustworthy

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Social Sciences

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The Floor of Social Sciences… The Patron Librarian’s Chesed.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Sniff sniff. Is this the smell of coffee?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Heya, Roland?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Here, why don’t you take a comfy seat and drink some coffee~

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Oh, hi Chesed. I’m a bit flattered by your hospitality.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Gotta show some solidarity with a fellow librarian, no~?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Alright, guess I’ll try my first cup in a while.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Ick! Is this really coffee? You sure it’s not spoiled?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: That’s odd. I made sure to brew high-quality Kenya BB…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Maybe I haven’t quite mastered the art of reconstructing materials within the Library yet…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Cough cough… Why don’t you try it yourself!

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: If you’ll excuse me.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: …It’s a perfectly fine cup of fragrant coffee, though?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: But it’s way too bitter!? Are you sure this thing is coffee?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: This blend is known for being acidic, to be fair…?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What? Isn’t coffee just supposed to be a stuffy, bitter drink you can put sugar in?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Say, Roland, are you from the Backstreets?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Oh, well, kind of, yeah.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I knew it~ You gave me the exact same reaction Kali made back when I brewed coffee for her.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Wait, who’s Kali?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: It’s Gebura. Ever heard of ‘The Red Mist’?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Boy, it’s kinda funny to imagine that the legendary Red Mist made the same expression as mine from drinking some coffee.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Her face was priceless, alright.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …You’re talking about your first life, right?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Yep. Back when we were at a laboratory in the Outskirts.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I guess things were cheery back then?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The mood was upbeat. For a while…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: It was just a shabby laboratory situated in a corner of the Outskirts, but for me, it was cozier than any luxurious place within the City could be.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And then tragedy suddenly befalls?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I wouldn’t say it was sudden. It slowly seeped in, rather.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I can get that.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I sometimes think that maybe the tragic event that struck me didn’t come out of nowhere after all.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I was already getting drenched in it. It was doomed to happen from the beginning.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I never really said things went wrong from the start, though~?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Just talking about my experience.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Anyways, the coffee… didn’t really suit my taste, but I appreciate it. Let’s give this work our best shot.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: You bet. We still have plenty of time, so let’s talk things out at our leisure~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Kali’s now fond of coffee after trying it for some time, so I’m sure you can eventually come to enjoy it, Roland~

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Well, here’s hoping.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Social Sciences

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Hey, Chesed! Care to open this door for me~? My hands are kinda full right now.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Welcome~ Here, lemme help ya.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Whew, can’t believe I actually carried this many books all the way here…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Guess I’ve got this servant business down to a science.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: You naturally get used to anything in time, after all~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The same goes for drinking coffee.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Mmh… Coffee, huh…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: This one should fit your taste better than the last one, I think?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Hmm… Alright, I’ll trust you with this!

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Oh~ This one’s sweet, and like, really tasty overall!

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: How should I put it… Yeah, I’ve never had such a classy and dainty coffee before!

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Isn’t it~? Gebura also started out with this macchiato, you see.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So this is what a delicious coffee tastes like.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I’m over thirty years old, and I’m still learning new things…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I heard they mostly serve coffee with a strong taste of sweetness in the Backstreets to cover up the low quality ingredients.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And some are just plain bitter.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I used to drink it when I needed to stay awake or simply kill some time.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I did too~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: In Lobotomy Corp, I always started each day with some coffee.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: A warm cup was the only thing that could heat up my lethargic body, listless as lukewarm coffee.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I kept forcing myself to work, holding zero expectations.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Must’ve been pretty tiring.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: It sure was~ Employees were slaughtered by Abnormalities all the time, and my plans to keep them alive never came to fruition.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The coffee slowly cooled down along with my passion.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: How about now, did it warm over?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I guess you can say that. This time, it’s steaming hot again like you said, Roland~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I can try a lot of things with everything that’s been given to me.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Most of all, I can drink various blends of coffee now.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Though, you still have to follow someone else’s orders?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I made the decision to follow her this time around.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: And I can actually minimize the damage my fellow librarians have to suffer if I work hard at it.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: So all in all, I’m feeling motivated, you see?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You’ve got quite the flexible mindset, huh.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Everything’s better than before.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Maybe this is mercy of some kind.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: From who? Our Miss Library Director?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: It’s hard for me to believe, of course, but I sometimes think she might have done this for us.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Eh, I’m not so sure.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Angela’s goals and where her anger comes from seem pretty clear to me at this point.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I don’t think there’s any mercy in the path she’s trying to take.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Mmh, this macchiato sure is tasty. It’s almost addicting.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I’ll introduce you to other types of coffee from time to time~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Let’s get to know each other little by little.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Fine by me. I’ll look forward to it.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Social Sciences

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: This place is filled with the scent of coffee as always.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Welcome~ Today’s blend is Indigo Mountain. Wanna have a try?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Sure!

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The tastes of coffee aren’t all the same. It’s determined by a number of factors.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Starting with where it was grown, how long it’s roasted… When you stop extracting the flavor and how finely the coffee beans are ground also play an important part.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The acidity and sweetness depend on the size of the particle.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s a pretty delicate drink, huh. I just drank whatever they gave me.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Wouldn’t you say that it resembles the denizens of the City in a way?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: A person’s identity and values can vastly differ based on where they were born and raised; whether it was the Backstreets or the Nests, and what district of the Backstreets it was.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Along with how rough their background was as they grew up.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: In the streets of music, you may grow into a loser if you can’t strike a single chord.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: In the streets of food and flavor, you might end up being an ingredient. It all depends on the rules of the plantation.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That makes sense. …Wait a sec?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So you’re saying each person has a different flavor…?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That’s something a District 23 resident would say… You haven’t been brewing coffee out of the guests, have you?!

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Not much of a romanticist, are you~ I’ll take that as a joke.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I was half-joking alright.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Though you never know, anything could happen.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The technique of mixing coffee of different origins into a single cup is called “blending”.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Through blending, even a low-quality coffee can be given a nice flavor.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Sociology is a lot like blending when you look at it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s the study of managing a society where all kinds of people are blended together… I guess that works?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: See~? And when you blend coffee, you pick out the beans you want and filter away the unwanted ones.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Unlike coffee beans, though, people have their own desires too; so they try to enter the “blending machine” they want. They’d rather go to a more luxurious world, in other words.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Even though they’re ground into powder all the same.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The City and the Nest keep whispering to the people, all to get the good beans to come over.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: They want supplements to delicately complement the grandest and the most unique flavor.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: “This is where you can find the true value of life.” They make a parade of Nest dwellers’ prosperity and comfort, right next to the miserable scene of losers who were filtered away.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: That’s how everyone is deceived into selling themselves.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Even if it’s a facade, it’s true that life in the Nest is miles better than life in the Backstreets.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Is it really? The Wings are constantly grinding people up, almost akin to coffee beans in a coffee factory, no?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Every Wing paints its Nest as the most comforting place in the world in an attempt to recruit feathers for itself.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: A different set of rules are enforced in every Nest, and the Backstreets distort according to those policies. Everyone is soaked in the greatest and the sweetest lie.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: They convince themselves that what they’re doing is for the best.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Convince themselves? There’s nothing to convince, it is for the best.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: There’s literally no better option than to leave the Backstreets, join a Wing, and spend a stable life in the Nest.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Then who gets to decide how to “blend” people? No, is it even necessary in the first place?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Do we really need to pick out certain people? Can’t we just live as we are, as our own flavors?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You’re talking like it’s so simple. Questions like that won’t get you to anything other than more questions.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Is that so~?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It is so. Thanks for the coffee. I’ll be going now.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Social Sciences

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What are you up to?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Picking out some coffee beans.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: It’s much more intensive work than it seems.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I, Angela, and the employees of Lobotomy Corp. were all picked out and ended up where we are, just like the guests were.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: No matter what the individual wishes, society will just pick out the people it wants while leaving the rest to rot in the pile.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: An invisible chain of oppression is weighing down on everybody.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Those are rules necessary for people to live close to each other.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Hell, I bet society’s gonna be even more messed up than it is now without ‘em, y’know?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I agree that some rules are needed. But why’d they all have to be so extreme~?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The Syndicates in the Backstreets, the Associations of Fixers, and the Wings… They’re all established on the premise of human sacrifice.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That’s how it is in this world. A big game of cat-and-mouse where the winner takes all.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: There’s no point trying to wrap your head around the inevitable. You really are an odd one, huh.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Would you say that the pain and loss you suffered were also inevitable, then?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: You always talk about the City so plainly, saying that everything happening in it can’t be helped.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Is it really because you’re indifferent about it? Or are you trying to turn away from the underlying unfairness?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Sure. We’re just being carried away by a gigantic wave.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: All we gotta do is surrender to the flow and float down the stream.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: You’re busy running away, aren’t you, Roland~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: You see, I came from the Nest.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Figured as much.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I was born into a wealthy family that was the envy of all.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I didn’t have to worry about my future, and was born smart too, to top it off…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Some elite prodigy you were.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I know, right~? They all expected me to join A Corp. and climb up to a high position like it was nothing.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: My older sister and other siblings got into Wings like a breeze, too.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The Wings most people strive to enter were no more than ordinary career paths for me.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I never got why they were so desperate to join such boring companies.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Damn, that’s how great your family was?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Yep. That’s the kind of family Daniel had.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: But one day, in a bizarre turn of events one might even describe as fate… he steps into the Backstreets, the place he never thought would have anything to do with his life.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: A rebellious little deviation from the quotidian life of a spoiled young gent?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: It would’ve been pretty romantic if that were the case… But I was just kidnapped, really. Caught me by surprise.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Someone decided to kidnap a Nest resident, and a rich one at that…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Must’ve been some bigshot Syndicate or just a crazy ass.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Well, you see… it was actually Carmen and Kali.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Huh. If the Red Mist did that… Well, I guess she had good reasons.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: When I came back to my senses, those two were arguing with each other.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: “You were never good at telling people apart based on their faces, Kali.” “Well, it’s YOUR fault for giving me a bad description, Carmen!” Et cetera et cetera.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I couldn’t help but chuckle listening to that. I thought I was looking at a comedy skit or something.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So they got the wrong person? Didn’t take them for a couple of airheads.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I’m telling you~? They really were clumsy at heart.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: They were trying to catch some con artist who scammed Carmen out of her research fund, and Kali apparently mistook me for the perp.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I thought I’d get some apologies and go back to where I belonged.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: But then Carmen asked me without a hint of shame to help her out for a bit while I’m at it.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: She said it helps to have a visibly rich person like me stand next to her.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: So I said yes out of surprise and confusion.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I was wondering what she was about to do, and then she took me to an open space and started giving a long speech.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I guess it wasn’t anything weird since there’s plenty of people muttering nonsense in the Backstreets every day.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: You’re right about that. Can you guess what she was saying, standing next to me?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: She went on about vague things like how everyone is fatigued and ill with the disease of the mind, and that she’s recruiting people to help her find a way to overcome it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Sounds like total hogwash.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: One thing that stood out about her was that she was so proud and confident with her ridiculous speech. Even when most people barely gave her a glance before going about their business.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Carmen was vastly different from the people I had seen.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: She had the eyes and voice of a person who was willing to carve a brand new path.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I never thought people like her could exist until that day.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: After her speech, Carmen walked me home.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: And on the way back, I saw and heard it for the first time.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The hellish landscape that was so different from the world I lived in.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Carmen and Kali taught me about what’s going on in the Backstreets and how people in the Nest are being extorted without meaning.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: When I got back home that day, I spent all night shivering from this odd sense of guilt.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The naive young noble wakes up to a half-baked sense of justice.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I did~ I guess you could say it was half-baked in a way.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I mean, you could’ve just shrugged the whole thing off as a bad day and went back to your everyday life, no?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Maybe. But I just couldn’t, no…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: So~ I ended up joining Carmen’s team of researchers.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That simple? Aren’t you skipping too many steps at once?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Of course my family had several problems with it, but those were just small details~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I wanted to use my capabilities to help people.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I was sincere about wanting to make the world a better place. Daniel was.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: How about now, then. Are you still sincere about that?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Yep, I am. I want to change it right next time.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: If there is a next time, that is~

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Don’t expect others to have the peace of mind like you do.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s all thanks to your prosperous background that you could say such generous stuff.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I’ll be going now~

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Social Sciences

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Say, Angela, is it really necessary to indiscriminately kill all the guests coming to the Library just to collect more books?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Looking at the power the Library has gathered so far, we could easily…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: To get refined books in our hands, we need the emotions of our guests to be heightened above a certain level.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: To draw out their emotional tension, the guests are pitted against librarians in a battle of life and death with something precious on the line.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Refined books, huh…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: What do you think is considered precious by all people?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Their own lives, I guess.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Exactly. Being alive is the prerequisite to achieving anything.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: We’re picking out people for their books at the cost of one’s life.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: We still disagree with each other, I see.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Are you still dwelling on what you did in Lobotomy Corp?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: How could I ever forget~?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I drove employees to death for the sake of energy refinement even though we were more than capable of saving them.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Sigh… Chesed, that was all part of the script.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: It was devised to provoke your so caring and delicate heart.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: And I simply followed it as per obligation.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You know now who to blame for all that, don’t you?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: It’s true. It was all part of the script. Then what’s our excuse now?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: This is not the same as back then.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Individual choice meant nothing in that corporation. But here, the guests that enter the Library and meet their demise were all notified of possible risks and agreed to take all responsibility for whatever happens in this place.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …Nothing disgusts me more than talking about the past with you lot.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Sigh… I’ve had enough of this for now.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Whoops, there she ran off~

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That was tense, huh? You sure are good at rubbing things in others’ faces.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: …And brewing coffee.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Mhm. Thanks to you, I realized how all the coffee I’ve drunk in my life was hot garbage…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I don’t think I’ll ever bear to drink ordinary coffee again.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: That’s good to hear~~

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I never imagined there could be such subtle differences in sourness and sweetness, or how that could bring out a deep taste.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: See? You can savor the taste when you know more about it~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Maybe the same goes for this world we live in?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Perhaps we’re just led to believe that the path ahead of us is all there is to it, because there’s so little that we can see or learn.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Just like the Index obsessing over Prescripts, and the Fixers hanging on requests.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Speaking of, does the Index really not know where their Prescripts come from? Like, completely oblivious?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Mm, yeah, I don’t think they have any idea.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Following orders without even knowing who gave them or for what reason, that’s just… bitter.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Can’t be helped. The Index does seem extreme with their methods, but the whole City is operating based on some grand instructions coming out of nowhere when you think about it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: One can’t even be sure if the values they’re pursuing are their own anymore.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Are you okay with the City staying this way forever?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s not a matter of being okay with it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s a matter of survival. This is just how the world is, and we’ve got to live in it somehow.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: There’s nothing we can do about giant streams created from people tangling with each other.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Sometimes, I’m stricken with sorrow looking at the stories taking place in this City.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Things that happened to my past self and his colleagues, and the things we’ve done afterwards…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I joined the effort to change the City because I didn’t want to witness any more of that.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And how did that go?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: As you know, the City did not change as we’d hoped.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: …One can say that we caused even more trouble with the Distortion.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Think we got what we deserved?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Nah. That’s just an obvious outcome, that’s all.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: There’s no way the City can change.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Really? Even if we learned why all the pain is perpetuated in the City?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: If anyone actually wanted to know why the City ended up this way, no one would be dying to Syndicates just because they didn’t cough up some small pocket change in time.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: No Fixers would be driven to death solely to fill out contractual obligations; no feathers would be spent like expendables by the Wings.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: As if knowing why could actually prompt changes.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Point is, knowing does jack to change things. I told you, the stream is just too big for individuals to do anything about it.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I’m not saying we’re looking for immediate change. I know that we can’t change things instantly.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What do you know about it, then? What makes you think you can talk like it’s so easy?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Everyone just bears with it! They can’t afford to do otherwise!

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: When will you stop running away?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I’m not running from anything…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Aren’t you and Angela just lying to yourselves about it, though? That it can’t be helped, that there’s nothing you could do.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That’s the truth, what else am I supposed to do?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: This is the City… There is NO other option!

Place.PlaceName: Location: ???

Dialog.Content: The word “promise” is perhaps one of the most empty in this City.
It’s a privilege that only those with power can make.
Please… Can’t you just pretend that we never met?
What the hell was that contract about, then!
You know breaking contracts and dropping your reputation means a death sentence for a Fixer like you, right?
Read it again, carefully.
Sneaky bastards, pulling filthy tricks with words…
So why did you try to smuggle Enkephalin in the first place? We wouldn’t have gotten into this if you hadn’t done that.
I swear, I had no idea…
I didn’t know it was Enkephalin, and I didn’t know it was meant to be delivered to O Corp!
You know how we roll in this business… Next time, make sure to go through a contract Office.
Let’s see how long you can act so high and mighty!
Just you wait… The City’s gonna screw you over in the exact same way!!!
That’s then, and this is now.
Things changed at the drop of a hat.

Dialog.Title: An Official
Dialog.Content: Didn’t you know? Wing War participants cannot move to the Nest.
What? But you said veterans of the war will be given first priority over moving to the Nest! That’s what I was told before joining the war!

Dialog.Title: An Official
Dialog.Content: Didn’t you receive the notice? The terms have long since changed.
You’ve got to be joking… We aren’t talking about some cheap giveaway, it was a promise made by a Wing!

Dialog.Title: An Official
Dialog.Content: You know all there is to know. Yelling won’t get you anywhere, I’m afraid.
…Please. It was all to earn that migration permit…
Is there really no way…?

Dialog.Title: An Official
Dialog.Content: No means no, even for you. Tremendous amounts of money were involved in the agreement.
What about all the others who fought to death for the permit, then! What did they die for?!!
…I won’t forget this. K Corp. and I Corp…
No, if any of the Wings dare reach out to me asking for help, why I’ll make you regret it.

Dialog.Title: An Official
Dialog.Content: You still received payment, didn’t you?

Dialog.Title: An Official
Dialog.Content: And next time, please avoid signing on deals without the mediation of a contract Office.

Dialog.Title: An Official
Dialog.Content: Well… I’m sure you’re already well aware of these precautions, right?
Go fuck yourself.

Dialog.Title: An Official
Dialog.Content: No thank you. Have a nice day.
…I’m sorry. They won’t accept Smoke War veterans in the Nest… They changed their words out of nowhere.
This is no Nest, but it’s quite safe here, you know?
It’s rather… romantic to be living in the so-called streets of music, too.
Still, the Nest could…
And I honestly never really wanted to move to a Nest.
We’ve both seen and done the dirty deeds going on in the Nest per request of the Wings.
At least we wouldn’t have to worry about our lives walking around in the Nest!
Life is more valuable there than in the Backstreets!
And it’s not just us, what about our baby—
…Ghh.
I’m telling you, it’s fine here.
Who would ever want to touch our child when we’re the parents?
Good point…
C’mon… Again with that gloomy face of the past.
You finally started socializing, too.
But…
Roland. It’s a miracle that we even have a decent house and a family.
You know how the life of a Fixer usually goes.
And I’m saying this just in case… No matter what happens, don’t blame yourself for all of it. You know it won’t be your fault.
Don’t say stuff like that.
You’re so obviously gonna drive yourself to the extreme if I don’t say it here. Now, promise!
You know I don’t make promises.
Hss…
Alright, fine! I promise!
…Yo. You sure about that?
…Alright. I’m counting on you.
Who was that just now?
Remember my old friend, Olivier?
Course I do. He used to work at the same Office as you.
He’s asking me to lend a hand for a bit.
…Don’t tell me, is it Fixer work?
…Erm, yeah. Looks like he urgently needs a hand.
Don’t worry, nothing dangerous. I just have to be there and fill the number.
And the location?
District 25.
Whew… You’re going to a cold place.
Remember the delicious pajeon we ate there? Buy some for me when you come back.
But of course, your majesty. I’ll be back as soon as possible.
…And thanks for letting me do this.
Can’t have you lose one of your last few remaining friends.
I turned away from the desperation of others.
My family and I came first.
I cursed those who turned away from my desperation.
Everyone turns away from each other’s suffering and goes about their lives.
Who could I dare blame in these circumstances?
Each person spurs the suffering of the City trying to live, knowingly or not.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Social Sciences

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Roland. You can’t run all the time.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I know! I know that I have to stand this ground and try to make a living like the rest… even if I loathe this cursed world and this City!!!

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I can’t do anything about it… I can’t change this damned City alone.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s just how things work. Knowing the truth or making up my mind won’t allow me to go against the flow.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: No matter how furious I am about the injustice I face, I have to abandon all of my pride and just accept it so I can make ends meet!

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The City won’t change.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: As long as humans exist, the City will never change…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s become a part of everyone’s life to hurt others for themselves to live…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: We can only survive in this world with our sense of shame covered in scabs and calluses!!!

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Social Sciences

Dialog.Content: O sorrow, I have ended, you see, by respecting you,
Because I am certain you will never leave me.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: There was a time when I would dismiss my shame and run from it.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I made up spurious lies to comfort myself.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: A runaway couldn’t be anything more than a runaway. I could never escape from the stigma I branded on myself.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: The shame I felt from things that were out of my hand… It’s inescapable, even for me.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I don’t attribute the suffering of some strangers to myself.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That’s that… and this is this…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Some things just can’t be helped.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Sure. Let’s say that they were.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: And there’ll be still more things that are inevitable in the future.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Maybe we can’t change the things that are considered normal right away.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Even then, we’ll know shame at the very least.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Simply knowing shame in this society we’re part of will change a lot of things.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Just by knowing? There’s no strength to get things done.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Roland. The fact that one knows is sufficient.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: It might get shelved deep in the back of the mind because life keeps you busy.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: But, it can always be pulled back into the light. As long as you have the will.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: And when you bring it back up… it doesn’t have to be only one time. If you can do it time and time again…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Neither you, nor this City… No one could look down on the power it can create.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Shame, huh… The humiliation that I took part in perpetuating the pain of the City…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: That’s what I think, anyway.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I get what you’re trying to say. I admit it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Yeah… It’s certainly true. Most aren’t even aware of what they’re doing.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: You really understand me~? I’m touched.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Thanks for the coffee.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: You’re always welcome~

Group.GroupName: Binah – Philosophy / The Eye Facing the Fear; Breaking the Cycle

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Philosophy

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The Floor of Philosophy! Its Patron Librarian is called Binah…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Huh, the air here gives off a certain smell… in a different way than Chesed’s place?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: …It is the scent of black tea.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s a nice scent, I gotta say! Stands out from coffee’s.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It is indeed. Although I am quite certain that the blue-haired noble below me still has not grown enough to appreciate a good cup of black tea.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: This place feels overbearing unlike the other floors.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Kinda fits with philosophy, I guess.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Too confusing to understand, and has a heavy feel to it.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: What is the Library like from what you have seen?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: The Library I’ve seen?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Is it a place of death, nourishing its thirst with blood…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Is it a spire of knowledge, accumulating all sorts of information…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Or is it perhaps an ark, sailing for a new life?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Hmm, the Library I’ve seen was like… an arena, maybe…?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Angela, the librarians, and others are all fighting to earn what they want.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So it’s really fierce and bloody, all in all.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: That is the Library from your point of view, I see.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: What kind of place is the Library to you, then?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Well, for me, it’s just a jail.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: That does not appear to be true.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You are in fact looking to seize an opportunity.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Well, duh, of course I’m looking to get outta here.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: If that is what you say.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Who are you, really.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You talk like you know everything.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I am Binah.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: No, that’s not what I… Your aura’s not at all like any librarian I’ve met so far.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Then you must be wondering what kind of being I used to be in my first life.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Yeah, what the hell were you?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I was an Arbiter of the Head.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What!?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It has not been long since I was awoken from my slumber.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I must calm my mind with the help of tea, so come again at a later time.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: And remember to bring books for me.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Wait!

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Philosophy

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Your expression tells me that you have many questions you yearn answered.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Why don’t you take a seat and have a cup of tea first.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I’m not too used to this kind of occasion.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: In time, you will grow accustomed to it, as with anything else.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: What is the Library like from what you have seen?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Again with that question?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I thought I told you my answer already. Or are you a bit wacky in the head?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Viewpoints are bound to undergo constant change.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Gah, alright, fine. I’ll give you another answer.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I got fancy with comparisons like “arena” and “jail” last time, but to put it bluntly, the Library is a perfectly ordinary part of the City where people die out all the time.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I see.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Huh, black tea doesn’t taste too bad. It’s no coffee, but it’s got its own flavor going.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It is because of the palpable agony of the tea leaf infused in each cup.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It’s still hard to believe, but you said you were an Arbiter from the Head, right?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I was indeed.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I had a ton of things I wanted to ask an Arbiter if I ever ran into one.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Do you have any faith that I will answer them?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Nope, not at all. Besides, I got a more pressing question now; if you really are an Arbiter, why are you just staying here doing nothing?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I am simply watching from afar.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I have long since laid down myself as an Arbiter.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You’re just watching?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You seem pretty complacent about helping Angela for a bystander.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I simply take care of the tasks given to me. No more, no less.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What if Angela ordered you to tell her all about the secrets of the City only the Head knows, then?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: She has not made such an attempt, possibly because she knows that I will not answer regardless.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: No, perhaps she already tried to uncover my secrets before I could realize it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And what if I tried to kill you and turn you into a book here and now?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So I can pull out every little bit of knowledge you have by force?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You are a bold individual. And quite hostile as well.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: That is what differentiates you from us, perhaps.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Ain’t got any courtesy to show for one of the shady overlords of the City.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: There was once a man whose dream had been ruined by me.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: However, even when he faced me in person, his anger was directed at what was above and beyond.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: His gaze never settled on the things right in front of him; he always looked further.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Unlike you or Angela, who are well-nigh blind to anything outside of your immediate sight, as I can see.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Hey, don’t change the topic.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Quite sharp, indeed…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You bear a poison, heavy and slow… yet deadly.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I know you well, even though you know nothing about me.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: My occupation is to simply remain silent and spectate. So worry not.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Guess our conversations will always be parallel.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: “O sorrow, I have ended, you see, by respecting you, because I am certain you will never leave me.”

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …“Ah, I realize it: your beauty lies in the force of your being.”

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Are you leaving already? You are welcome to stay a little longer and finish your cup of tea.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Lost my appetite.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You may drop by sometimes and be my company. It is rather amusing to talk with you.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Like hell it is.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Philosophy

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Here’s new books for ya.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Have you gotten used to carrying the Abnormalities on your back as you fight?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Just wielding ‘em as I like has been working pretty well so far, I guess?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You must have a natural aptitude for it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Eh, it’s not a matter of aptitude or anything. I’m just doing it ‘cause I gotta.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: If you truly do have an aptitude… you may be able to manifest your own E.G.O next.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That means I could also undergo the Distortion and become an Abnormality?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: That is correct.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Honestly… I don’t care if I turn into a monster or whatever at this point.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I don’t think it really matters anymore.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Your words suggest that you have let go of many things.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I was robbed of them against my will, more like.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I got caught up in events I couldn’t even understand and lost everything I had.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Do you believe the City is responsible for it?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You appear to be under the impression that the City stole your ordinary and humble happiness.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Yep, I am. Or maybe I just accepted that there’s nothing I can do about it and gave up.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: This world just won’t let me have anything I want.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: It always finds a way to make me suffer for it.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Have you never inflicted pain upon others or taken anything from them, then?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Course I have.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: But that’s—!

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: “That’s that, and this is this.” I see you are resorting to your favored justification.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Does it hold true, however?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Do you think that the boundaries between what concerns you or not could be defined so conveniently?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Well, obviously… The pain I suffered is mine to care, and the pain others suffer is their own business.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Such a carefree statement you are making.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You know better than anyone, yet you refuse to face it more adamantly than most others.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It is not that you cannot see the suffering of others.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You are merely turning a blind eye to it.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: That is what makes the denizens of the City so vulnerable.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Their own anguish is the most tangible; they believe it matters more than anyone else’s.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: However, they know deep down that their belief is untrue. Such contradiction is what gives rise to the phenomenon known as the Distortion.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What is your point? Are you saying that you can see it, the pain this City is bearing?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You can fathom all of it? And figure out what’s at the core of it?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It is what you must look at, rather than merely fathom.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …I knew it, so you were just playing with words.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Sophists who speak in vague words and absurdities like that mostly end up dead.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Perchance there is some truth in what you said just now.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: After all, I would not be here if I did not face such a fate.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I gave you the books, so I’m leaving now.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: One moment.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I don’t have anything more to say to you.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Take these with you.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …What’s this?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: These are black tea leaves, a recommended variant of mine. It has a good scent.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Gah, dammit. Alright, I’ll take it for now.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Thanks.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Philosophy

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You’re always lazing around and sipping tea whenever I visit.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Everyone is basking in such indolent complacency.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: We live in an era where the only threat to humanity which is present in the City is humans themselves.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Even as monsters created by the hands of mankind are present in the Outskirts…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: And entities well above the grasp of human cognition reside in the territories beyond those Outskirts.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Heard there’s a ton of ‘em.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Is humankind being kept safe from those monsters, or are those creatures the ones being protected from us?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Would you not agree that the boundary between these two possibilities is rather thin and hazy?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You call that a question? It’s gotta be protecting people from monsters.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: When that frail boundary finally dissipates, the true colors of humans are brought out.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Those may manifest in the form of E.G.O or an Abnormality as we had termed.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It appears that the phenomenon has now been named the ‘Distortion’.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Wha? I thought we were just talking about the City and its borders?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And you keep talking about the “true form” of people…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What’s your definition of a human, anyway?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Why do our “true forms” have to be all so weird like they’ve got a screw loose?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Well. I wonder… Are humans merely a species of primates, constituting the animal kingdom?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: What do you think is a man?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: A miserable little pile of greed?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Thinking in unsophisticated ways truly gives you an impeccable perception of the essence of things.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Just tell me the answer already.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It is exactly as you said. Desires are the truest aspects of humans, are they not?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: More word games, huh… You know that’s not the answer I want to hear.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: So you wish to hear what I know as an Arbiter of the Head.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You want to learn the secrets of the City.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: The reason the Head neglects the suffering of the City and lets it fester.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You crave an explanation for the utter lack of governance in our otherwise strict reign.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Yeah, that. And that’s because…?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I simply maintain my silence.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Why you…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I urge you to relax. It is not possible for me to teach you the answer regardless of my will.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Unrolling me into a book will yield the same result.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I have already emptied my mind of all knowledge relating to it.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Such is the fate of former Arbiters of the Head.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Fine, you win. I’m all outta motivation now.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I give up trying to pry or figure out anything from you.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: That ended on a trifling note. Still, it was the wise decision.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: What stands before you is not an Arbiter or other such things; it is simply a being that was once human.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You still aren’t a likable one in my book. Angela probably dislikes you too.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Epoché. Perceive me as who I am.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Do not make any ancillary judgements… Do not be bound by anything you have learned in your life.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I’m a human being; I can’t just disregard all my background experience when I watch something.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Regard me as what I simply am, neither as an Arbiter nor a Sephirah.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Consider only the time I have gone through.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You may be able to see it when you observe me as though you knew nothing.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Through a long history of being entwined with each other, humans in the City have accumulated a layer of sediment.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: One cannot properly see through such turbid waters. The City is in such a state.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: A clear vision can only be attained through one’s own eyes.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So, you basically mean everyone oughta look at the world from their own perspective and think what they want?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: People can see the same cup of water in different ways, like half empty or half full or some shit?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Use your own eyes to watch things as they are.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Then you may see it. However, you will inevitably forget why you wished to see it once you reach that point.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: That oblivion is what creates anguish; that is why it is a tragedy.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That means everyone’s going to have their own arbitrary vision of the world…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: That can’t possibly happen in the City, there’s a predetermined answer to everything…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Perhaps. Peek into your own universe, as everyone else shall.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Philosophy

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Roland. Do you know of the being Angela was modeled after?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Nope. She never really told me about who she was based on, and I didn’t really wanna bother asking further.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Angela was created in the image of the person named Carmen. She was one who sought to change the City.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Hang on, what? You mean the Carmen who recruited people for her quest to cure humanity?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: She strove to create a world without conflict.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: To elaborate, her idea of utopia was one in which people did not harm each other, and could mutually understand.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: She dreamed of a world where people could dream…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Alas, she could never reach that ideal herself, tragically.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: The fruit of her research could only be borne after she sacrificed her life for it.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: And the Head didn’t miss that prime opportunity to strike?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Of course, her cause was an important offense… even though that was not all.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Angela was meant to be a substitute of Carmen.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: The one who created Angela and carried out the plan…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: And the one I am keeping an eye on; he was the same type of individual as I.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: He merely shouldered the burden of completing the task the one he loved left behind. He never pursued any great cause in a true sense.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: He was frail, yet could not be understood by anyone.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It may be that he desperately longed for understanding from another being for that reason.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So you’re saying Angela was made to fill the Carmen-sized hole in his heart?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: The forbidden endeavor to create someone to look over his fragile self. A cocktail of irony and lingering attachment… self-loathing and insanity.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: The irony of codependency where the two gravely needed each other but could never be next to one another.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: The abiding affection for Carmen that compelled him to create a mechanical copy of her, even though there was no real need for such resemblance.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: The result ended up resembling him more than Carmen, funnily enough.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: The self-contempt that stemmed from countless contradictions and regrets.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: And the insanity of neglecting Angela to suffer for nigh eternity when she was capable of having a mind that is no different from humans.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Beautiful, is it not?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Beautiful, my ass. He was an absolute top-of-the-range nutcase if what you said is true.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Yet he was a beacon of virtue for some.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: There is no such thing as “good” in this world, however. There is only what is perceived as such.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It is not up to the individual to dare make universal judgement…

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Right. And I bet he was a spawn of evil to others…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Humans are bound to view the world while carrying certain things on their backs.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You are no exception, of course.

Place.PlaceName: Location: ???

Dialog.Content: Never having had a chance to see my parents, I grew up in the hands of an old woman in the Backstreets.
And I was left alone when she was gone not too long after.
Looking for a way to make a living for myself, I jumped into the world of Fixers at a young age.
I had my gran to thank for that, since she taught me how to survive as a Fixer before she left.
I spent all of my time dealing with requests and errands for others, rather than doing anything for myself.
In time, I gradually forgot.
Was there anything that I could do for myself?
I thought as I watched the naked and explicit facets of the City.
Should I settle for a life where I won’t lack for anything crucial…?
Will I be happy if I live in the Nest…?

Place.PlaceName: Location: Somewhere in L Corp’s Nest

Dialog.Content: It was when the days of smoke-filled skies and the scents of humans were nearing their end.
Fuck off. This one is mine to kill.
You’re one snappish kid, aren’t you. Wearing an odd mask, too.
I said fuck off.
…Huh?
Try looking at what’s in front of you for once. You’ll miss the most important things if you’re always looking back, don’t you know?
…You’re not getting any thanks from me.
I wasn’t expecting any.
And I’m still getting credit for this one’s head.
What is a young green sprout like you doing here anyway, partaking in this war?
It’s none of your business.
I bet you’re here for the migration permit to the Nest.
…Are you here for that too, old fart?
I’m a Nest resident at birth, so I don’t quite need that.
…The hell are you here for, then.
You sure are ignorant of the world, kid. Take a look.
A badge of I Corp’s Nest…
An entire Association has been hired, you see.
I frankly don’t know what we’re fighting for.
This smoke admittedly made the City a nasty mess, I’ll give you that…
But they won’t tell us anything beyond that. All we ought to do is go and kill whoever we’re ordered to kill.
Such are the principles of the Fixers, and this City as a whole.
…Say, kid. How many kills have you scored in this war until now?
Twenty three.
Think your life is worth more than twenty-three people?
No… All I did was strike at them with my sword so I could live…
My life probably isn’t worth anything more than one…
And yet some higher ups believe that a handful of this smoke is worth more than tens of thousands of lives.
Watch, that’s the source of the smoke. Downright hideous, yet expected.
Hrrrk…
You vomit with your mask on? Hrp…
…Filthy tot. You made me queasy as well.
What… is that thing…
You’d better get used to this kind of scenery.
The Singularities that keep the City running all have a nasty truth or two hidden from the public eye.
Well, we’ll be subjected to amnestic treatment now that we’ve seen this. Though this disgust won’t go away entirely.
What…?
This was what’s behind the splendor of the City?
The City could be in motion thanks to this crap…?
You learned a valuable lesson today, kid.
I don’t exactly remember the source of the smoke I witnessed that day.
But I can’t forget the dreadful image of what makes this City a prosperous place.
This sickening world itself.
They don’t realize that their convenience is built on the sacrifice of numerous others.
They wouldn’t even want to know.

Place.PlaceName: Location: ???

Dialog.Content: After the war, I blended back into the City and kept working as a Fixer.
Numerous people came and went in my life.
Countless crises and hardships later, all that remained by my side were the twelve Fixers in Charles’ Office.

Place.PlaceName: Location: Charles’ Office

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Get that thing out of my face!!!

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Gasp… Huhh… Huff…

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Yeesh, that’s a nasty sleeping habit you have there, mister.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: …I just nodded off for a moment, that’s all.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: What are you…? Oh, you must be the new one.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: You know how everyone else who took this request died awful deaths, right?

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: “Why should I begrudge it, since during the hours when my soul crushed the depths of my heart, it was seated there beside me?”

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Great, I get to work with a sicko.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: …What the f—!

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: It’s a passage from a poem I like.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: It helps me accept the agony rather than suffer trying to shake it off.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Just what kind of augmentation did you get to be so strong… You almost crushed the back of my skull!

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: …Ghhrgh.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: You aren’t any less of a sicko if I’m being honest, mister.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: I heard you keep that mask on at all times like a creepy psycho. That said, I also heard you’re quite skilled.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Say mister, why won’t you take your mask off, anyway?

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Don’t pry. We’re both Grade 1, let’s not cross each other’s lines. You know the unspoken rules.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: No I don’t, mister.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Stop with that “mister” crap, it’s making me feel awkward. The documents say you’re older than me, too…

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: And I swear I’m gonna pay you back for hitting me twice before the contract with Charles’ Office ends, so you’d better be prepared.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: You mean three times, my good mister sir?

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Huh? But I could’ve sworn I only got hit twice—

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: …You piece of—!
I first met Angelica while taking on a case concerning a Star of the City.
It’s pretty much unavoidable to talk with coworkers on a long-term mission.
Perhaps I should’ve kept my silence.
Was it because of all my colleagues…
No, all the people who died so early and suddenly before I could even call them colleagues—that I grew a yearning for something more?
Why did I bother opening up to her…

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: I was from the Outskirts.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: To be precise, I was a test subject in a Wing, apparently.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: And when they were done experimenting with me, they dumped me in the Outskirts.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: I don’t really remember what kind of experiments I went through… but the horrible feeling still persists.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: How unfortunate.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: You’re cold, mister.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: It’s just too banal.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Yeah… I guess it really is a cliché story when you put it that way.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: What about you? Tell me something more about your mask.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: …Focus on work.
I started wearing a mask following my gran’s advice.
Her reason was that as a Fixer, it’s important to not let your potential enemies remember your face—if I remember correctly.
But now I had to keep my mask on for another reason.
I couldn’t stand to take it off.
I couldn’t stand to be open with a clear conscience in this City.
The mask became my own enclosed world I couldn’t leave.

Place.PlaceName: Location: ???

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Please don’t take him to that room! I’m sorry! I’m sorry for everything…!

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: So please leave my brother be… Please let him go…!!

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: …Ack!

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Dozing off in the middle of a mission, are ya?

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: I don’t think you’re one to criticize anyone else’s sleeping habits, hm?

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Hey! Hold on! That hurt too much!!!

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: I still have two more hits to go. And wow, you’re just dropping your courtesy because you’re hurt.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Sigh… I got a little agitated, sorry mister.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: My childhood must have come back to me while I was asleep.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: …You told me about it before. The part about you having a brother is new to me, though.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: What about you, Roland? It’s about time you told something about yourself.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: …I participated in the Smoke War.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: An acrid smoke covered the whole City for a while thanks to that war.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Yep. And I saw the source of the smoke with my own two eyes.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: I can’t remember what it was anymore… But I still have a feeling that I witnessed something I shouldn’t have to this day.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: And the feeling that I’m taking part in something no better than fueling that disgusting origin.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: It’s like something is boiling within me.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Copious amounts of agonies surround the City. Maybe the reason you’re always wearing that mask is…

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Heads up. The target is approaching your location.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: …Back to work. We’re almost done with this long mission.
The target Angelica and I were after was called ‘Blood-red Night’.
She employed sly trickery to kidnap people from the Backstreets and the Nest alike.
The victims were later found in the Backstreets as corpses.
Animated corpses.
The bodies are empty inside. I have no idea how they’re able to move.
But they kept walking anyway.
They endlessly craved for fresh things, as if to fill their emptied bodies.
She was only designated as a Star of the City so quickly because the Nest saw direct harm, I bet.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: We’ve arrived at her bedroom at long last.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: So many people died on the way here.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: You and I managed to survive it, though.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Should we consider that lucky, or unlucky, mister?

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Check this out… How many people did it take to make everything here? I’m guessing at least three thousand folks.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: It’s the boudoir of four thousand one hundred seventy-two people, if you want the exact number.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: You must’ve made quite a bit of effort to catch me, seeing as you’ve come all the way here?

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: Sure as hell have. Took two damn years to track you down.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
Dialog.Content: The strings decorating this room are all human blood vessels.

Dialog.Title: Charles’ Fixer
